description:
Upon launch opened a terminal box for less than 1 second then crashed. Attempted launch via terminal & elevated privileges with same result.
Ubuntu 
Log: g_environ_setenv: assertion 'value != NULL' failed
Log: _g_io_module_get_default: Found default implementation gvfs (GDaemonVfs) for ‘gio-vfs’
Ubuntu 19.10
On Ubuntu 19.04. The application won't open when I try to launch it
Useless - crash on 18 without any feedback.
summary: Useless - crash on 18 without any feedback

description:
Installed from software centre - no joy

In terminal

>sudo apt install libimobiledevice-utils

 made directory iphonebackups in home folder

>idevicebackup2 backup ~/iphonebackups/

perfect backup

2020-04-29 

I got instructions from this web page 
https://www.systutorials.com/how-to-backup-iphone-on-linux/
The app just doesn't open, no error, no logs :(
summary: The app wont open, on Ubuntu 18.04.4. LTS

description:
Thanks to Gordon who posted earlier. 
Confirmation this approach works:

Ubuntu 18.04 and an iPhone 6 Model MQ3D2B/A 

In terminal

>sudo apt install libimobiledevice-utils

 mkdir ~/iphonebackups

>idevicebackup2 backup ~/iphonebackups/

perfect backup
summary: Installed via terminal - and it works. Ubuntu 18.04 and an iPhone 6

description:
For my Ubuntu 20.04 installation on my DELL XPS 9300, I believe unfavorable reviews are unwarranted for libimobiledevice.

I was able to mount my iPhone and make a complete backup. However, I did have to use Terminal after the Ubuntu Software snap attempt didn't appear to provide the necessary utilities for the libimobiledevice library.

The following command lines gave excellent results:

sudo apt install libimobiledevice6 libimobiledevice-utils

idevice pair

# Trust dialogue appears on iPhone and requires pwd for the iPhone.

# A success message appeared after running this. 

SUCCESS: Paired with device

# Then, run the following to allow connections:

usbmuxd -f -v

# This allows for multiple connections between your iPhone and your Ubuntu installation.

# Another package called iFuse can be used to mount your iPhone manually but I didn't need it.

sudo apt install ifuse

# This will install iFuse and any additional packages it might need on your Ubuntu installation.

# Your iPhone file system should appear in 'Files' if you are using the GNOME desktop. You can then remove or add files to the device treating it as your own external drive.

# Thanks also to Ben Stockton who provided the above code and instructions. Ben is a UK based tech writer. Full details can be found at:

https://www.maketecheasier.com/easily-mount-your-iphone-as-an-external-drive-in-ubuntu/

and

https://apple.stackexchange.com/questions/291014/backup-from-iphone-on-linux-without-itunes
summary: May Require Some Command Lines in Terminal

description:
This version worked on my older iPad, but does not work on the newer iOS. 
Version 1.3.0 is available which supports beyond iOS 9(?), but will not install on Ubuntu 18.04 or 20.04. Installers still claim 1.2 is up-to-date and instructions available for building from source are incomplete.
